{{good article}} {{Infobox Military Structure |name=Walmer Castle |partof= |location=[[Walmer]], [[England]] |coordinates= |image= [[File:Entrance to Walmer Castle - geograph.org.uk - 237099.jpg|250px]] |caption= The gatehouse |image2= |caption2= |map_type= Kent |latitude= 51.200992 |longitude= 1.402308 |type= [[Device Fort]] |code= |built= 1539 |builder= |materials= |height= |used= |demolished= |condition= |ownership= [[English Heritage]] |open_to_public= Yes |controlledby= |garrison= |current_commander= |commanders= |occupants= |battles= |events= [[English Civil War]]
[[Napoleonic Wars]] }} '''Walmer Castle''' is an artillery fort originally constructed by [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]] in [[Walmer]], [[Kent]], between 1539 and 1540. It formed part of the King's [[Device Fort|Device programme]] to protect against invasion from France and the [[Holy Roman Empire]], and defended the strategically important [[the Downs|Downs anchorage]] off the English coast. Comprising a [[keep]] and four circular [[bastions]], the [[moat]]ed stone castle covered {{convert|0.61|acre}} and had 39 firing positions on the upper levels for [[List of medieval and early modern gunpowder artillery|artillery]]. It cost [[the Crown]] a total of £27,092 to build the three castles of Walmer, [[Sandown Castle, Kent|Sandown]], and [[Deal Castle|Deal]], which lay adjacent to one another along the coast and were connected by earthwork defences.{{efn|name=Money16thC}} The original invasion threat passed, but during the [[Second English Civil War]] of 1648–49, Walmer was seized by pro-[[Cavalier|Royalist]] insurgents and was only retaken by [[Roundheads|Parliamentary forces]] after several months' fighting. In the 18th century, Walmer became the official residence of the [[Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports]] and was gradually modified from a military fortification into a private residence. Various [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Ministers]] and prominent politicians were appointed as Lord Warden, including [[William Pitt the Younger|William Pitt]], the [[Duke of Wellington]] and [[Granville Leveson-Gower, 2nd Earl Granville|Lord Granville]], who adapted parts of the Tudor castle as living spaces and constructed extensive gardens around the property. By 1904, the [[War Office]] agreed that Walmer had no remaining military utility and it passed to the [[Ministry of Works (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Works]]. Successive Lord Wardens continued to use the property but it was also opened to the public. Walmer was no longer considered a particularly comfortable or modern residence, however, and [[Lord Curzon]] blamed the poor condition of the castle for [[Mary Curzon, Baroness Curzon of Kedleston|his wife's death]] in 1906. Lord Wardens since the [[Second World War]] have included [[Winston Churchill]], [[Robert Menzies]] and [[Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother]], but they have made only intermittent use of Walmer Castle. In the 21st century, Walmer Castle is run as a tourist attraction by [[English Heritage]]. The interior of the castle displays a range of historical objects and pictures associated with the property and its Lord Wardens, protected since the 19th century by special legislation. The grounds include the Queen Mother's Garden, designed by [[Penelope Hobhouse]] as a 95th birthday gift for Elizabeth in 1997. ==History== ===16th century=== Walmer Castle was built as a consequence of international tensions between England, [[Kingdom of France|France]] and the [[Holy Roman Empire]] in the final years of the reign of King [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]]. Traditionally [[the Crown]] had left coastal defences to the local lords and communities, only taking a modest role in building and maintaining fortifications, and while France and the Empire remained in conflict with one another, maritime raids were common but an actual invasion of England seemed unlikely.{{harvnb|Thompson|1987|p=111}}; {{harvnb|Hale|1983|p=63}} Modest defences, based around simple [[blockhouse]]s and towers, existed in the south-west and along the [[Sussex]] coast, with a few more impressive works in the north of England, but in general the fortifications were very limited in scale.{{harvnb|King|1991|pp=176–177}} [[File:Walmer or Sandown (Kent) castle, 1539 draft.jpg|thumb|upright|left|An 1539 early design for either Walmer or nearby [[Sandown Castle, Kent|Sandown Castle]]]] In 1533, Henry broke with Pope [[Paul III]] in order to annul the long-standing marriage to his wife, [[Catherine of Aragon]] and remarry.{{harvnb|Morley|1976|p=7}} Catherine was the aunt of [[Charles V of Spain|Charles V]], the Holy Roman Emperor, and he took the annulment as a personal insult.{{harvnb|Hale|1983|p=63}}; {{harvnb|Harrington|2007|p=5}} This resulted in France and the Empire declaring an alliance against Henry in 1538, and the Pope encouraging the two countries to attack England.{{harvnb|Morley|1976|p=7}}; {{harvnb|Hale|1983|pp=63–64}} An invasion of England appeared certain.{{harvnb|Hale|1983|p=66}}; {{harvnb|Harrington|2007|p=6}} In response, Henry issued an order, called a "[[Device Fort|device]]", in 1539, giving instructions for the "defence of the realm in time of invasion" and the construction of forts along the English coastline.{{harvnb|Harrington|2007|p=11}}; {{harvnb|Walton|2010|p=70}} Walmer and the adjacent castles of [[Deal Castle|Deal]] and [[Sandown Castle, Kent|Sandown]] were constructed to protect [[the Downs]] in east Kent, an important anchorage formed by the [[Goodwin Sands]] which gave access to [[Deal, Kent|Deal Beach]], on which enemy soldiers could easily be landed.{{harvnb|King|1991|p=178}}; {{harvnb|Harrington|2007|p=16}} The stone castles were supported by a line of four earthwork forts, known as the Great Turf, the Little Turf Bulwark, the Great White Bulwark of Clay and the Walmer Bulwark, and a {{convert|2.5|mi|km|adj=mid|-long|1}} defensive ditch and bank.{{harvnb|Harrington|2007|p=16}} Collectively the castles became known as the "castles of the Downs" and cost [[the Crown]] a total of £27,092 to build.{{harvnb|Harrington|2007|p=8}}{{efn|name=Money16thC|Comparing early modern costs and prices with those of the modern period is challenging. £27,092 in 1539 could be equivalent to between £15.3 million and £6,960 million in 2014, depending on the price comparison used, and £174 to between £98,000 and £44 million. For comparison, the total royal expenditure on all the Device Forts across England between 1539–47 came to £376,500, with [[St Mawes Castle|St Mawes]], for example, costing £5,018, and [[Sandgate Castle|Sandgate]] £5,584. £500 in 1648 could be equivalent to between £60,300 and £16.7 million.{{harvnb|Biddle|Hiller|Scott|Streeten|2001|p=12}}; {{cite web | url=http://www.measuringworth.com/ukcompare/ | title=Five Ways to Compute the Relative Value of a UK Pound Amount, 1270 to Present| author1 = Lawrence H. Officer | author2= Samuel H. Williamson | postscript =none | mode = cs2|date = 2014| accessdate=29 May 2015 | publisher=MeasuringWorth}}}} Walmer was built between April 1539 and autumn 1540, by a team including Richard Benese as the surveyor, William Clement as the master carpenter, and Christopher Dickenson as the master mason.{{harvnb|Harrington|2007|p=8}}; {{cite web|url=http://www.bl.uk/onlinegallery/onlineex/unvbrit/a/001cotaugi00001u00021000.html|title=A Colored Bird's Eye View of "A Castle for the Downes"; Probably an Early Design for Walmer and Sundown Castles|publisher=British Library| mode = cs2|access-date=26 June 2015}} It was initially garrisoned by a captain, two lieutenants, two porters, ten gunners and three soldiers, at an annual cost of £174.{{harvnb|Elvin|1890|p=162}}{{efn|name=Money16thC}} It was probably equipped with a range of [[brass]] and [[cast-iron]] [[List of medieval and early modern gunpowder artillery|guns]], along with [[arquebus]]es and [[bow and arrow|bows]] for close defence.{{harvnb|Coad|2008|p=28}} In 1597, a report listed the castle's artillery as comprising a [[cannon]], a [[culverin]], five [[demi-culverin]]s, a [[Saker (cannon)|saker]], a [[Minion (cannon)|minion]] and a [[Falconet (cannon)|falcon]]. ===17th century=== [[File:Walmer Castle aerial view.jpg|right|thumb|upright=1.4|Aerial view of the castle seen from the north-east, showing the later alterations to the upper storeys, with the gatehouse to the upper right]] Walmer Castle was left to decline in the early 17th century, with little money being made available for repairs and the garrison receiving low pay, leading some members to reside in nearby Deal rather the fort itself, and to take on additional employment to supplement their wages.{{harvnb|Coad|2008|p=30}} Walmer Castle was seized by Parliamentary forces at the start of the first [[English Civil War]] between the supporters of King [[Charles I of England|Charles I]] and [[Parliament]], but did not play a significant role in the remainder of the initial conflict.{{harvnb|Elvin|1890|p=183}} After the few years of unsteady peace after 1645, the [[Second English Civil War|Second Civil War]] broke out in 1648, this time with Charles' Royalist supporters joined by Scottish allies. The Parliamentary navy was based in the Downs, protected by Walmer and the other Henrician castles, but by May a Royalist insurrection was under way across Kent.{{harvnb|Harrington|2007|p=50}}; {{harvnb|Kennedy|1962|pp=251–252}} Vice-Admiral [[William Batten]] had been forced to resign from his post as Commander of the Fleet the previous year by Parliamentary officials, and he now encouraged the fleet to join the Royalist faction.{{harvnb|Kennedy|1962|pp=248–250}}; {{harvnb|Harrington|2007|p=50}} Sir Henry Palmer, a former sailor, accompanied by other members of the Kentish gentry, also called on the fleet to revolt, taking advantage of the many fellow Kentish men in the crews.{{harvnb|Ashton|1994|p=440}} Walmer and Deal Castle declared for the King, shortly after the garrisons at Sandown.{{harvnb|Kennedy|1962|pp=251–252}} With both the coastal fortresses and the navy now under Royalist control, Parliament feared that foreign forces might be landed along the coast or aid sent to the Scots.{{harvnb|Ashton|1994|pp=439–440}} Parliament defeated the wider insurgency at the [[Battle of Maidstone]] at the start of June, and then sent a force under the command of Colonel [[Nathaniel Rich (soldier)|Nathaniel Rich]] to deal with Walmer and the other castles along the Downs.{{harvnb|Ashton|1994|p=440}}; {{harvnb|Harrington|2007|p=51}} Walmer Castle was the first to be besieged, and surrendered on 12 July.{{harvnb|Harrington|2007|p=51}} Deal was attacked in late July, and in August artillery assaults began on Sandown as well, leading to the surrender of both remaining fortifications.{{harvnb|Harrington|2007|p=51}}; {{harvnb|Ashton|1994|p=442}} Walmer was badly damaged during the conflict and it was estimated by Rich, responsible for carrying out the repairs, that the work would cost at least £500.{{harvnb|Coad|2008|p=31}}{{efn|name=Money16thC}} In 1649, Parliament ordered new supplies of ammunition and powder be sent to Walmer and the other castles of the Downs, which were brought back into good order.{{harvnb|Elvin|1890|p=210}}; {{harvnb|Coad|2008|p=31}} The garrison at Walmer remained substantial during the period, with a governor, a corporal and 20 soldiers, but when [[Charles II of England|Charles II]] was [[Restoration (England)|restored to the throne]] in 1660 he reduced the numbers again to a captain, lieutenant, porter and 16 men.{{harvnb|Elvin|1890|pp=211–213}} In the [[Glorious Revolution]] of 1688 against Charles' brother, King [[James II of England|James II]], the townsfolk of Deal seized Walmer Castle on behalf of [[William III of England|William III]], the [[Prince of Orange]].{{harvnb|Elvin|1890|p=224}} By the end of the century, however, the castle was increasingly regarded as out of date from a military perspective. ===18th–19th centuries=== ====1700–1828==== [[File:Isaac Cruikshank - A New Catamaran Expedition!!! (1805).jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|A satirical cartoon of 1805, depicting [[William Pitt the Younger]] directing operations against the French from Walmer Castle (left)]] In the 18th century, Walmer Castle became the official residence of the [[Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports]]. The Lord Warden was originally a medieval title linked to [[Cinque Ports|five key ports]] along the coast of England; the position's prominence had faded, but it still retained important judicial and military functions.{{harvnb|Coad|2008|p=29}}; {{harvnb|Elvin|1890|pp=236–237}} When [[Lionel Sackville, 1st Duke of Dorset|Lionel Sackville]], the [[Duke of Dorset]], was appointed to the post in 1708 he decided that the existing residence in [[Dover Castle]] was unsatisfactory, probably because of the semi-ruinous state of the castle, and moved into Walmer Castle instead.{{harvnb|Coad|2008|pp=30–31}} The Duke occupied the post of Lord Warden until 1765, save for two periods when it was filled by [[James Butler, 2nd Duke of Ormonde|James Butler]], the [[Duke of Ormonde]] and [[John Sidney, 6th Earl of Leicester|John Sidney]], the [[Earl of Leicester]].{{harvnb|Coad|2008|p=29}} He carried out extensive work to make the castle more habitable, building extensions towards the north bastion and constructing a small house in the south bastion for the soldiers. Under the subsequent Lord Wardens, the politicians [[Robert Darcy, 4th Earl of Holderness|Robert Darcy]], the [[Earl of Holderness]], and [[Francis North, 1st Earl of Guilford|Francis North]], the [[Earl of Guildford]], the castle continued to house artillery but it became increasingly less military in character.{{harvnb|Coad|2008|pp=29, 31–32}} The [[Prime Minister]] [[William Pitt the Younger]] was then made the Lord Warden in 1792. Pitt was badly in debt and King [[George III of England|George III]] believed that the post, which came with a salary of £3,000 a year, would usefully supplement Pitt's income.{{harvnb|Coad|2008|pp=29, 32}}; {{harvnb|Shepherd|2008|p=8}}{{efn|name=Money18thC|Comparing 18th century costs and prices with those of the modern period depends on the measure used. £3,000 in 1792 could be equivalent to between £326,000 and £23.4 million in 2014, depending on the price comparison used.{{cite web | url=http://www.measuringworth.com/ukcompare/ | title=Five Ways to Compute the Relative Value of a UK Pound Amount, 1270 to Present| author1 = Lawrence H. Officer | author2= Samuel H. Williamson | postscript =none | mode = cs2|date = 2014| accessdate=29 May 2015 | publisher=MeasuringWorth}}}} Pitt made extensive use of the castle and by 1803 he used it as his main residence in an effort to reduce his living costs.{{harvnb|Coad|2008|pp=29, 32}}; {{harvnb|Shepherd|2008|pp=8, 10}} Pitt's niece, Lady [[Hester Stanhope]], joined him at Walmer between 1803 and 1806; together with Pitt, she carried out extensive work on the castle gardens, transforming them from a simple [[kitchen garden]] into a set of landscaped ornamental enclosures; Stanhope enlisted the Dover militia to help with the [[landscaping]] and planting.{{harvnb|Coad|2008|p=30}}; {{harvnb|Hinze|2008|pp=16–17}} With the outbreak of the [[French Revolutionary Wars]], Pitt became energetically involved in the protection of the ports along the coast, entertaining the local garrison commanders, naval captains and the local gentry at Walmer on a regular basis.{{harvnb|Elvin|1890|pp=246–247}} After Pitt resigned as Prime Minister in 1801, fears remained of a French invasion and he formed a volunteer cavalry unit at Walmer Castle, where he lived with his new officers.{{harvnb|Elvin|1890|pp=248–249}} He also formed a unit of bombardier infantry and a fleet of 35 fishing boats called [[lugger]]s, which he armed with {{convert|12|lb|adj=on}} or {{convert|18|lb|adj=on}} guns, reviewing them from the castle.{{harvnb|Elvin|1890|pp=248–250}} Stanhope remarked on the constant drilling of army units around the castle during her time there.{{harvnb|Elvin|1890|p=250}}; {{harvnb|Hinze|2008|p=22}} [[Robert Jenkinson, 2nd Earl of Liverpool|Robert Jenkinson]], the [[Earl of Liverpool]], took possession of Walmer Castle following the death of Pitt in 1806. Liverpool was a favourite of King George's, and his appointment as Lord Warden was again intended to provide a valuable income and a country retreat.{{harvnb|Brock|2014|p=14}} As Prime Minister, Liverpool used Walmer as a personal retreat and as a location for private political discussions with selected guests.{{harvnb|Brock|2014|p=14}}; {{harvnb|Muir|2015|p=332}} ====1829–99==== [[File:Duke of Wellington's room, Walmer Castle.jpg|thumb|left|The [[Duke of Wellington]]'s room, including his original chair and camp bed]] On Lord Liverpool's death, [[Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington|Arthur Wellesley]], the [[Duke of Wellington (title)|Duke of Wellington]] and the current Prime Minister, asked King [[George IV of England|George IV]] for the post of Lord Warden, primarily because he was seeking the use of Walmer Castle.{{harvnb|Muir|2015|p=332}} Wellington took up post in 1829 and considered Walmer to be "the most charming marine residence". He made use of the castle each autumn, entertaining extensively there but living and sleeping in a single room.{{harvnb|Coad|2008|p=32}}; {{harvnb|Shepherd|2008|p=5}} He was visited there twice by [[Queen Victoria|Victoria]], once when she was still a princess and later as queen.{{harvnb|Coad|2008|p=32}} Wellington let the gardens fall into a poor condition.{{harvnb|Elvin|1890|p=257}} Wellington died in his room at Walmer on 14 September 1852.{{harvnb|Coad|2008|p=32}}; {{harvnb|Elvin|1890|p=275}} His body was kept in a [[death chamber]] in his room to lie in state until 10 November, and when the room was opened for public visitors during the final two days, around 9,000 attended.{{harvnb|Elvin|1890|pp=275–276}} The Duke's body was finally removed to London via Deal, complete with a military escort.{{harvnb|Elvin|1890|p=276}} [[James Broun-Ramsay, 1st Marquess of Dalhousie|James Broun-Ramsay]], the [[Marquess of Dalhousie]] became Lord Warden; on his death, the Prime Minister [[Henry John Temple, 3rd Viscount Palmerston|Henry Temple]], the [[Viscount Palmerston]], took over the castle in 1861. Palmerston initially declined to buy the contents of the castle from his predecessor's estate on taking up the post, a practice which had become traditional for the Lords Warden, complaining about the high price being proposed.{{harvnb|Shepherd|2008|p=5}}; {{harvnb|Maxwell|1893|pp=326–327}} This raised the risk that the historical contents of the castle might be sold off at open auction; and some of Wellington's former belongings were therefore removed by his family for safekeeping. The politician Lord Granville was offered the post of Lord Warden by the new Prime Minister, [[John Russell, 1st Earl Russell|John Russell]] in 1865.{{harvnb|Fitzmaurice|1905a|p=489}} Russell noted that the role would be expensive for Granville to perform — the salary had been abolished in 1828 — but that it would provide him with a property by the sea, which Granville had been seeking to acquire for a while.{{harvnb|Fitzmaurice|1905a|p=489}}; {{harvnb|Coad|2008|p=29}} Granville took over Walmer in 1865. He expanded the gardens, built new kennels for a hunting pack and spent many years reassembling the furniture and other objects that Pitt and Wellington had used at the castle.{{harvnb|Maxwell|1893|p=327}}; {{harvnb|Coad|2008|p=29}}; {{harvnb|Fitzmaurice|1905a|p=490}} He received large numbers of visitors, many of whom stopped off while travelling to or from France.{{harvnb|Fitzmaurice|1905b|pp=130–131}} The diplomat Baron de Malortie visited Granville and his family at Walmer, and later praised the homely atmosphere in the castle. He described how, after breakfast, the family and guests would all gather in the drawing room, which was the only large room in the house, and Granville would answer government correspondence amid the daily life of the rest of the household.{{harvnb|Fitzmaurice|1905b|pp=129–130}} The businessman and politician [[William Henry Smith (1825–1891)|William Smith]] was appointed Lord Warden in 1891, but died in Walmer Castle during his first visit here in October of that year.{{harvnb|Shepherd|2008|p=13}} Smith had proposed that the historical artefacts in the castle should be protected from being removed by later Lord Wardens and suggested that government pass an Indenture of Heirlooms Bill. The government carried out the plan after Smith's death, protecting almost 70 pieces of furniture and 50 artworks at the castle and forbidding them being moved from the castle without the [[Secretary of State for War]]'s approval.{{harvnb|Shepherd|2008|pp=5, 13}}; {{harvnb|Maxwell|1893|p=328}} [[Robert Gascoyne-Cecil, 3rd Marquess of Salisbury|Robert Gascoyne-Cecil]], the [[Marquess of Salisbury]], became the next Lord Warden; with adequate legal protection now in place, the [[Henry Wellesley, 3rd Duke of Wellington|3rd Duke of Wellington]] suggested returning his grandfather's possessions to the castle, but [[Georgina Gascoyne-Cecil, Marchioness of Salisbury|Lady Salisbury]] declined the offer.{{harvnb|Shepherd|2008|p=6}}; {{harvnb|Maxwell|1893|pp=327–328}}; {{harvnb|Coad|2008|p=29}} ===20th–21st centuries=== [[File:Walmer Castle - central corridor.jpg|thumb|upright|The central corridor on the first floor of the castle, looking north]] By 1904 the [[War Office]] had concluded that Walmer had no remaining military value and agreed to transfer the castle to the [[Office of Works]], who accepted it on the condition that they were paid £2,400 in order to carry out repairs.{{harvnb|Fry|2014|pp=11–12, 15}}{{efn|name=Money20thC|The equivalent value of early 20th century money in the modern period depends on the measure used. £2,400 in 1903 could be equivalent to between £241,000 and £2.3 million in 2014, depending on the price comparison used.}} The Office's survey noted that "the lower floor ... is very inconvenient, dark and not conducive to health while the women servants have to sleep in a sort of dormitory in the slopes of the roof... The principal floor is, generally speaking, badly arranged and badly lighted and the Dining Room is very small"; the report suggested that it would be best to demolish the building and rebuild it.{{harvnb|Fry|2014|p=15}} Proposals were made to find the next Lord Warden, [[George Curzon, 1st Marquess Curzon of Kedleston|George Curzon]], the [[Marquess Curzon]], alternative accommodation and the [[Royal Marines]] were approached as replacement tenants for the castle, but declined the offer. The Ministry acquired agreement for most of the castle to be opened to the public, with various historical objects related to the property being put on display, including some donated by King [[Edward VII of England|Edward VII]].{{harvnb|Fry|2014|pp=15–16}} Lord Curzon moved into the castle when returned from India in 1905. His wife, [[Mary Curzon, Baroness Curzon of Kedleston|Mary]], fell ill, which Curzon believed to be a result of their poor accommodation, and despite being moved to a new residence, she died shortly afterwards.{{harvnb|Coad|2008|p=33}} As a result, Curzon decided to resign the post of Lord Warden, leaving the castle, and subsequently the Prince of Wales, the future [[George V of England|George V]], took up the post. [[William Lygon, 7th Earl Beauchamp|William Lygon]], the [[Earl Beauchamp]], became the Lord Warden in 1913, building a [[Roman Catholic]] [[chapel]] at the castle and holding large parties there each summer.{{harvnb|Coad|2008|pp=34–35}}; {{harvnb|Mulvagh|2008|p=355}} His children later commented that they found the castle was chilly and cramped.{{harvnb|Mulvagh|2008|p=355}} The Prime Minister, [[H. H. Asquith|Asquith]], was invited by Beauchamp to use the castle during the [[First World War]] as a weekend retreat, as it had good communication links with the front line in France.{{harvnb|Coad|2008|p=35}}; {{harvnb|Jenkins|2002|p=295}}; {{harvnb|Mulvagh|2008|p=320}} Asquith's wife, [[Margot Asquith, Countess of Oxford and Asquith|Margot]], was not initially impressed by Walmer, noting in her diary that while it was "very distinguished" and had "great charm", it was "terribly exposed" with "cold... noisy corridors and small rooms"; she later came to like the castle and noted that she was sad to finally leave it.{{harvnb|Brock|Brock|2014|pp=66, 100}} Lygon had sexual relations with men, which was illegal in England during this period.{{cite web|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/34643|title=Lygon, William, seventh Earl Beauchamp (1872–1938)|publisher=Oxford University Press|edition=online|date=2011|author=Richard Davenport-Hines|mode=cs2|accessdate=31 July 2015}} Rumours spread about the parties that he had held at Walmer Castle after the war, where, according to the historian [[Richard Davenport-Hines]], he had "behaved indiscreetly with young men".{{harvnb|Mulvagh|2008|p=372}}; {{cite web|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/34643|title=Lygon, William, seventh Earl Beauchamp (1872–1938)|publisher=Oxford University Press|edition=online|date=2011|author=Richard Davenport-Hines|mode=cs2|accessdate=31 July 2015}} The King was informed about his lifestyle and Lygon fled the country in 1931, resigning the appointment of Lord Warden the following year. [[File:Walmer Castle Three seaward facing cannons.JPG|thumb|left|Three cannons on the one of the castle's firing platforms]] Lygon's successor, the politician [[Rufus Isaacs, 1st Marquess of Reading|Rufus Isaacs]], the [[Marquess of Reading]], became the Lord Warden in 1934, holding jovial family gatherings there.{{cite web|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/34119|title=Isaacs, Rufus Daniel, first marquess of Reading (1860–1935)|publisher=Oxford University Press|edition=online|date=2011|author=A. Lentin|mode=cs2|accessdate=31 July 2015}} His wife, [[Stella Isaacs, Marchioness of Reading|Stella]], attempted to restore Wellington's old bedroom to its earlier appearance during the Duke's tenure and, as part of this project, the [[Arthur Wellesley, 4th Duke of Wellington|4th Duke of Wellington]] agreed to send the original contents of the room back to the castle, where they still remain.{{harvnb|Shepherd|2008|p=6}} The politician [[Freeman Freeman-Thomas, 1st Marquess of Willingdon|Freeman Freeman-Thomas]], the [[Marquess of Willingdon]], became Lord Warden in 1936, followed by Sir [[Winston Churchill]] who followed him in 1941 during the [[Second World War]]. Churchill noted to the [[John Reith, 1st Baron Reith|Minister of Works and Buildings]] that he had told King George V on taking up the position that he doubted that he would be able to live at Walmer Castle during the war, as it was within range of the German artillery along the French coast, or indeed that he would able to afford to live there afterwards, and for that reason he hoped that the state would maintain the castle and gardens, and decide what use it should be put to after the war.{{harvnb|Churchill|1948|p=737}} Sir [[Robert Menzies]], the Australian politician, became the Lord Warden in 1965 and visited the castle on an annual basis, staying in the flat there.{{harvnb|Vickers|2006|p=416}}; {{cite web|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/31438|title=Menzies, Sir Robert Gordon (1894–1978)|publisher=Oxford University Press|edition=online|date=2011|author=A. W. Martin|mode=cs2|accessdate=31 July 2015}} [[Elizabeth the Queen Mother]] followed Menzies in 1978, initially visiting the castle from the Royal Yacht, but from 1986 onwards taking over the entire castle for three days each July.{{harvnb|Vickers|2006|p=416}} This required moving furniture, silverware and other furnishings from London and caused difficulties for English Heritage, who managed the property.{{harvnb|Vickers|2006|pp=416–417}} The current Lord Warden, [[Michael Boyce, Baron Boyce|Admiral the Lord Boyce]], took up his post in 2004. In the 21st century, the property is managed by [[English Heritage]], attracting 77,828 visitors in 2014.{{cite web|url=http://alva.org.uk/details.cfm?p=423|title=Latest Visitor Figures|publisher=Association of Leading Visitor Attractions|accessdate=31 July 2014|mode=cs2}} English Heritage carried out a £674,000 programme of improvements to the castle in 2015 intended to improve the visitor experience.{{cite web|url=http://www.kentonline.co.uk/deal/news/walmer-castle-will-undergo-improvements-30752/|title=Walmer Castle Will Undergo Improvements to Help Cement its Place in History|publisher=Kent Online|author=Eleanor Perkins|accessdate=31 July 2015|mode=cs2|date = 26 January 2015}} The castle is protected under UK law as a [[scheduled monument]], while the surrounding gardens are protected with a grade II [[listed building|listing]].{{cite web|url=http://list.historicengland.org.uk/resultsingle.aspx?uid=1013381|title=List Entry Summary|publisher=Historic England|mode=cs2|accessdate=31 July 2015}}; {{cite web|url=http://list.historicengland.org.uk/resultsingle_print.aspx?uid=1000291|title=List Entry Summary|publisher=Historic England|mode=cs2|accessdate=31 July 2015}} ==Architecture== ===Castle=== [[File:Walmer Plan, modern labelled.png|thumb|upright=1.2|Plan of the ground floor of the castle; key: A - gatehouse; B - porter's lodge; C - gunpowder store; D - servant's hall E - Hall Room; F - Gunners' Lodging; G - Willingdon Room; H - Sackville Room]] Walmer Castle retains most of its original 16th-century structure, with a tall [[keep]], {{convert|83|ft}} across, at the centre, flanked by four rounded [[bastion]]s, one of which served as a [[gatehouse]], and a [[moat]], surrounded in turn by a [[curtain wall (fortification)|curtain wall]].{{harvnb|Harrington|2007|p=21}}; {{harvnb|Rutton|1898|p=26}}; {{harvnb|Saunders|1989|p=38}} Its curved walls are {{convert|15|feet|m}} thick.{{harvnb|Saunders|1989|p=38}} It was nearly identical to its sister castle at Sandown and was approximately {{convert|167|by|167|ft}} across, covering {{convert|0.61|acre}}.{{harvnb|Rutton|1898|p=26}} The historian [[John Rigby Hale|John Hale]] considered the original castle to form a transitional design between older medieval English designs and [[Star fort|newer Italian style]]s of defence.{{harvnb|Hale|1983|p=73}} The castle had three tiers of [[List of medieval and early modern gunpowder artillery|artillery]] – the heaviest and longest range weapons occupying the upper levels, including the keep – with a total of 39 firing positions, and 31 [[gunloop]]s in the basement for [[handgun]]s should close defence be required.{{harvnb|Harrington|2007|p=21}}; {{harvnb|Saunders|1989|p=38}} The [[embrasure]]s in the walls were all widely splayed to provide the maximum possible space for the guns to operate and traverse, and the interior of the castle was designed with vents to allow the smoke from its guns to escape. From the 18th century onwards, the interior of the castle was converted to provide accommodation for the Lord Wardens, almost all of which is now open to visitors. The castle is still entered through the ground floor of the gatehouse in the western bastion, which contains the original porter's lodge.{{harvnb|Coad|2008|p=37}} In the middle of the castle is the keep, which originally housed the Servants' Hall and now a set of tea rooms. In the southern bastion is a set of rooms which are reached through the Hall Room, originally built as gunners' lodgings in the 18th century and converted into the entrance hall to the castle in the 1930s.{{harvnb|Shepherd|2008|pp=2–3}}; {{harvnb|Coad|2008|p=37}} On the far side of the bastion are the Sackville and Willingdon Rooms, built in the 18th century; the Willingdon Room is now used as a museum for objects relating to William Pitt.{{harvnb|Shepherd|2008|p=3}} The Lucas Room has been redecorated in a mid-19th century style and is used to present various items of Wellington memorabilia.{{harvnb|Shepherd|2008|p=4}} The north and east bastions are filled in, providing solid foundations for the gun platforms above. The second floor contains the Lord Warden's private apartments in the west bastion and the western half of the keep. In the southern bastion is the Duke of Wellington's Room and the Lucas Room, originally part of an apartment of rooms selected by William Pitt for his use, as they formed the warmest part of the castle.{{harvnb|Shepherd|2008|p=5}} The corridor running across the castle through the keep was built by Pitt to link the north and south halves of the castle.{{harvnb|Shepherd|2008|p=8}} The Prince Consort's and Queen Victoria's rooms in the keep are named after their use during the royal visit of 1842, although their decoration today dates from the [[interwar period]].{{harvnb|Shepherd|2008|pp=10–12}} The Dining Room, Drawing Room and Ante Room, which overlook the northern bastion, date from the 1730s, when the Duke of Dorset constructed them to form a private set of chambers.{{harvnb|Shepherd|2008|p=14}} These rooms feature a range of pink and purple window glass, which tradition says was installed by the Earl of Liverpool to protect his wife's eyesight; recent analysis shows that some of the pink-tinted glass dates from the 1730s, and discoloured naturally over time, while other panes were intentionally purchased around 1800 in these hues, but probably as status symbols and not for any medical purpose.{{harvnb|Dungworth|Girbal|2011|pp=13–14, 44–45}} ===Gardens=== [[File:Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother's garden, Walmer Castle.jpg|thumb|The Queen Mother's Garden]] The gardens of Walmer Castle date mainly from the 1790s and 1860s and comprise around {{convert|13|ha|order=flip}} of land, split evenly between formal ornamental gardens and [[Landscaped parkland|parkland]].{{harvnb|Hinze|2008|pp=16–17}}; {{cite web|url=http://list.historicengland.org.uk/resultsingle_print.aspx?uid=1000291|title=List Entry Summary|publisher=Historic England|mode=cs2|accessdate=31 July 2015}} The main body of the gardens stretches away from the castle towards the north-west, and is made up of protected, well-drained, [[chalk]]-based soil, forming a maritime [[microclimate]].{{harvnb|Hinze|2008|pp=16–17}} The castle is approached through the castle [[meadow]], an area of open parkland, lined with [[Holm oak]]s planted in the 1860s, and is surrounded by the dry moat, now a garden dating from at least the 1850s and planted with trees and shrubs.{{harvnb|Hinze|2008|pp=18, 22}}; {{cite web|url=http://list.historicengland.org.uk/resultsingle_print.aspx?uid=1000291|title=List Entry Summary|publisher=Historic England|mode=cs2|accessdate=31 July 2015}} Adjacent to the castle are the Queen Mother's Garden and the [[kitchen garden]] and [[Greenhouse|glasshouses]]. The Queen Mother's Garden was built by English Heritage as a 95th birthday gift for the then Lord Warden in 1997, the site having been originally part of the wider kitchen gardens, before being turned into a [[tennis court]] in the 1920s. Designed by [[Penelope Hobhouse]], the garden incorporates [[Classical architecture|classical]] and [[Islamic architecture|Islamic]] themes, with a 92-foot-long (28 m) pool, a viewing mound and a classical pavilion. The two glasshouses have been restored, functioning as cold greenhouses, while the remainder of the kitchen garden is planted with a mixture of vegetables, fruit trees and flowers.{{harvnb|Hinze|2008|p=22}}; {{cite web|url=http://list.historicengland.org.uk/resultsingle_print.aspx?uid=1000291|title=List Entry Summary|publisher=Historic England|mode=cs2|accessdate=31 July 2015}} The 262-foot-long (80 m) Broadwalk is the main axis of the gardens and separates the glasshouses from the 328-foot-long (100 m) Oval Lawn, planted with [[lime tree]]s and [[yew]]s.{{harvnb|Hinze|2008|p=19}}; {{cite web|url=http://list.historicengland.org.uk/resultsingle_print.aspx?uid=1000291|title=List Entry Summary|publisher=Historic England|mode=cs2|accessdate=31 July 2015}} The Broadwalk is lined by the "Cloud Hedge", a formal 19th-century yew hedge that grew out of control in the Second World War and was left in its current, undulating style.{{cite web|url=http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/visit/places/walmer-castle-and-gardens/things-to-see-and-do/broadwalk/|title=Walmer Castle's Broadwalk|publisher=English Heritage|accessdate=8 August 2015|mode=cs2}} Two terraces in the middle of the garden, designed by [[William Masters (botanist)|William Masters]] in an [[Italian garden|Italianate]] style, separate the further half of the garden.{{harvnb|Hinze|2008|p=20}} On the other side are the paddock, planted with Holm oaks, and a curved belt of woodland of [[beech]], [[Fraxinus|ash]] and [[chestnut]] trees, badly damaged in the storms of [[Great Storm of 1987|1987]] and [[Burns' Day storm|1990]].{{harvnb|Hinze|2008|p=20}}; {{cite web|url=http://list.historicengland.org.uk/resultsingle_print.aspx?uid=1000291|title=List Entry Summary|publisher=Historic England|mode=cs2|accessdate=31 July 2015}} At the far end is the Glen, a woodland hollow formed from an old chalk quarry in the 19th century.{{harvnb|Hinze|2008|p=21}} ==See also== * [[Castles in Great Britain and Ireland]] ==Notes== {{notelist|notes=}} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==Bibliography== * {{cite book | last1= Ashton | first1 = Robert | authorlink = Robert Ashton (historian) | title = Counter-revolution: The Second Civil War and Its Origins, 1646–8 | date = 1994 | publisher = The Bath Press | location = Avon, UK | isbn = 9780300061147 | ref= harv}} * {{cite book | last1= Biddle | first1 = Martin | last2= Hiller | first2 = Jonathon | last3= Scott | first3 = Ian | last4= Streeten | first4 = Anthony | title = Henry VIII's Coastal Artillery Fort at Camber Castle, Rye, East Sussex: An Archaeological Structural and Historical Investigation | date = 2001 | publisher = Oxbow Books | location = Oxford, UK | isbn = 0904220230 | ref= harv}} * {{cite book | last1= Brock | first1 = Michael | last2= Brock | first2 = Eleanor | title = Margot Asquith's Great War Diary 1914-1916: The View from Downing Street | date = 2014 | publisher = Oxford University Press | location = Oxford, UK | isbn = 9780198229773 | ref= harv}} * {{cite book | last1= Brock | first1 = W.
